page.title: 07WILDLIFE OF FROXFIELD AREA
page.content: There are large numbers of animals in the area, and a bird population in almost every hedge. These birds are mostly common, and include tits, thrushes, finches, and sparrows. Sparrow-hawks and kestrels also live in the region. Most of these birds live on the edge of the woods, for a greater food supply. Foxes in the area are very common, and are concentrated in the woodland. Badgers inhabit the sides of the steep scarps. Field mice, voles, and shrews are found in the area, and even some dormice, and these animals live in the open, scrubby wood. The most common deer in the area are Fallow and Roe. Sika deer are quite uncommon and a herd of red deer also run through this area.
